citation.article-title: ‘Candidatus Pasteuria aldrichii’, an obligate endoparasite of the bacterivorous nematode Bursilla
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: ‘Candidatus Pasteuria aldrichii’ (al.dri′chi.i. N.L. masc. gen. n. aldrichii of Aldrich, named in honour of Dr Henry Aldrich for his many contributions to research and teaching in microbiology at the University of Florida).

‘Candidatus Pasteuria aldrichii’ [(Firmicutes) NC; G+; M; NAS (GenBank no. GU186440); morphology (see following description); S (Bursilla sp. RGD244 (sp. PS1179), pseudocoelom)] Giblin-Davis et al., 2004, this study.

Obligately endoparasitic bacterium of the pseudocoelom of Bursilla nematodes that cannot be cultivated on cell-free media, only by attachment of endospores to species of the genus Bursilla and co-cultivation in soil with bi-weekly inoculations of nematodes.
Host infection is via cuticular penetration by attached endospores, occurring at all stages of host development, except L1 and egg stages.
Sporogenesis, which leads to the death of the host, occurs in the pseudocoelom of L3-stage through to adult-stage nematodes.
Sporogenesis is typical of other nematode-specific species of the genus Pasteuria. Host range appears to be limited to species of the genus Bursilla.
Cells are non-motile with a Gram-reaction-positive vegetative phase. ‘Mycelium’ is septate, hyphal strands branch dichotomously with expansion of hyphal tip forming early sporangium.

SEM and TEM reveal dorsal peripheral fibres of the host-attached mature endospore, which are covered with a dense layer of adhesion fibres, except for a slight gap encircling the endospore that appears to be diagnostic for this species.

Lateral views with TEM show that the peripheral fibres comprise thin ‘wing-like’ structures that are narrowly (1/6–1/3 the height of the lateral wall) attached to the anterior-most region of the lateral walls of the spore.

This is a diagnostic feature, relative to other species of the genus Pasteuria described from nematodes where the peripheral fibres are broadly attached to the lateral walls of the spore (>2/3 the height of the lateral wall).

In lateral views with TEM, the ratio of the combined widths of the dorsal and ventral adhesion layers relative to the peripheral fibre layers is about 2 : 1 in ‘Candidatus Pasteuria aldrichii’ versus ~1 : 5 in all other described species of bacteria from nematodes.
The sporangium and central-body diameters overlap with other described species of the genus Pasteuria identified from nematode hosts.

In lateral views with TEM, the shape of the central body is a rounded-ellipse, similar to the circular shape seen in P. ramosa, which contrasts with the rectangular to rounded-trapezoidal shape seen in transverse sections of ‘Candidatus Pasteuria usgae’, the horizontally oriented elliptical shapes seen in P. penetrans and P. nishizawae, and the rounded-square shape seen in P. thornei.

The outer spore coat of ‘Candidatus Pasteuria aldrichii’ is thickest dorsally, and thinnest across the bottom of the spore, which contrasts with ‘Candidatus Pasteuria usgae’, which is seven to eight times thicker laterally than across the bottom, and with all other described species, having outer spore coats with relatively uniform thickness.
No basal ring exists around the pore opening, as in P. penetrans.

There are no lateral microprojections of the outer spore coat as there are in ‘Candidatus Pasteuria usgae’, P. penetrans and P. nishizawae. The epicortical wall remnant of the mature endospore is difficult to discern in TEM sections but appears to be concentric in lateral view, similar to what has been described for P. ramosa, P. nishizawae and P. penetrans.
Spores are not found in distinctive clumps from the disintegration of the mother thallus as described for the putative ‘Candidatus Pasteuria hartismeri’ (Bishop et al., 2007).
